a novel class of 2D MAX@titanate nanocomposits was fabricated by a simple oxidation and alkalization

Two‐Dimensional MAX‐Derived Titanate Nanostructures for  Efficient Removal of Pb(II) 
Pengcheng Gu,a,b Sai Zhang,a Chenlu Zhang,a Xiangxue Wang,a Ayub Khan,a  Tao Wen,a* Baowei  Hu,b* Ahmed Alsaedi,c Tasawar Hayat,c and Xiangke Wanga,b* 
Two‐dimensional (2D) nanomaterials have been well identified as one of the promising star materials benifting from  their  great promise for waste treatment. Nowadays, the investigation of wastewater remediation is highly imperative and still  challenging. Here, a novel class of 2D MAX@titanate nanocomposits was fabricated by a simple oxidation and alkalization  method,  which  exhibited  different morphologies  and  impressive  elimination  performance.  The  Pb(II)  uptake  processes  were  dramatically  affected  by  solution  pH  and  reached  equilibrium quickly.  Abundant  functional  groups  and  enhanced   specific surface areas endowed T‐NTO nanofibers with an outstanding adsorption capacity of 328.9 mg g‐1 at pH= 5.0 and  T= 298K, which was much higher than that of T‐KTO nanoribbons. Moreover, the possible mechanism was expounded with  aid of Raman, FT‐IR, XRD and XPS analyses, in which the synergistic effect of surface complexation and ion exchange made  tremendous contribution to the adsorption performation. On the basis of above analyses, this work not only presented a  novel and facile strategy for preparing T‐NTO and T‐KTO nanostructures as superior adsorption capacity, but aslo broaden  other functional MAX‐derived nanostructures’prospective application in environmental cleanup. 
Introduction  The contamination of heavy metal ion is a significant public and environmental concern due to its underlying threaten to human beings and the ecological environment.1-3 Among the heavy metal pollutants, Pb(II) ions, which are highly toxic and capable of bioaccumulation, could cause serious ecological and health issues even in trace concentration.4-6 Hence, remediation of wastewater containing Pb(II) manifested a great practical value for mitigating the risks to the human beings and environmental ecosystem.7,8
Currently, two-dimensional (2D) materials have prompted great research interests by virtue of their unique and impressive structural properties.9,10 Specifically, MAX-phase-derived 2D materials, referred as “Mxenes”, acted a vital role in the optimization of rechargeable batteries and supercapacitors, etc.11,12 As the promising star of energy storage, Ti3C2Tx (Tx = -F, -OH) was most studied subset of “Mxene” materials, which was exfoliated by etching the “Al” element from its Ti3AlC2 precursor.13,14 Unfortunately, the absence of abundant functional groups, introduction of fluoride ions, greatly hindered its inherent capacity in the purification of wastewater.15  To address this issue, numerous investigations have been devoted to design functionalized Ti3AlC2 (TAC) derived nanostructure for optimizing its adsorption performances, for instance, the synthesis of hydroxylated Ti3C2Tx by an alkalizationintercalation strategy and fabricating hydrated Ti3C2Tx as a high efficient U(VI) adsorbent.16,17 Although these optimization methods were skillful and effective for increasing the functional groups of Ti3C2Tx, the fluoride-containing etching procedure inevitably limited its practical applications.18 Therefore, designing novel functionalized TAC-derived materials with well layered nanostructures using a straightforward and eco-friendly method, was of great importance for wastewater remediation. Owing to the fact that the unique structures and abundant oxygen-containing groups, titanate nanomaterial were regareded as the promising ones for capturing pollutants.19,20 Hence, the combination of TAC with abundant active sites of titanate materials was a wise and effective choice. To our best knowledge, few studies regarding the elimination of heavy metal ions with TAC-derived titanate naonmaterials have been published.
Inspired by this point, herein, two types of TAC@titanate composites were successfully fabricated by the simultaneous alkalization and oxidation of irregular TAC directly. The synthetic process of TAC@titanate composites was shown in Fig. 1. The introduction of multi-functional oxygen-containing groups on TAC by fluoride-free strategy was undoubtedly beneficial for the enhancement of adsorption performance.21 Systematic investigations of adsorption process of Pb(II) on the as-prepared T-NTO and TKTO were evaluated by batch experiments, which involved the effect of pH, contact time and temperature, etc. Moreover, the

adsorption mechanisms were subsequently verified by Raman, FTIR and XPS analyses. The investigation herein endowed the TACderived nanostructure a promising material for management of Pb(II) from aqueous solution.
NaOH&H2O2 KOH&H2O2
TACT-NTO T-KTO
Fig. 1 Schematic diagram of T‐NTO and T‐KTO nanostructure formation.  
Experimental section  Preparation of adsorbents 
Typocally, a mixture of 200 mg of Ti3AlC2 powders (purchased from Forsman Technology Company), 75 ml of 5 M (12 g) NaOH, and 3ml of 30% H2O2 was placed into a beaker. After magnetic stirring for 8 h, the suspension was transfeered to a Teflon-lined stainless-steel reaction vessel, and then be kept in an oven a temperature of 180 oC for 24 h. The gray product was collected by deionized water until the pH decreased to 6. Likewise, T-KTO was prepared by an analogous procedure using KOH (15 g) as alkali source. The detailed information for the characterization was described in SI.
Adsorption experiments 
A typical batch experiment was as follows, the target Pb(II) stock solution (300 mg/L), T-NTO or T-KTO suspension (1.2 g/L), deionized water and background ions (NaNO3) were successively added to a 10mL polyethylene tube to achieve the desired concentrations. The suspensions were shaken for 24 h and separated by filtration. The Pb(II) concentration was detected by a spectrophotometric method at the wavelength of 616 nm. The solution pH was adjusted by the addition of 0.005 M-0.1 M HNO3 or NaOH. For the adsorption isotherm studies, the adsorption experiments were explored under different initial concentrations (5- 70 mg/L) at pH = 5.0. Kinetics investigation of T-NTO and T-KTO (m/V= 0.2 g/L) were determined at various contact time (2-360 min). Details for the corresponding kinetic models employed in this study were listed in SI. The adsorption percentage (%) and the adsorption amount (qe, mg g-1) were caculated from the following equations:
 0 1ee V C C
q m

where C0 (mgꞏL-1) is the preliminary concentration and Ce (mgꞏL-1) is the equilibrium concentration after adsorption, m (mg) represents the mass of T-NTO or T-KTO, V (mL) is the volume of the suspension.
 
Result discussion   Characterization 
The structures and surface morphologies of the pristine Ti3AlC2, TNTO and T-KTO samples were characterized by TEM and SEM. As evidenced from Fig. 2, the SEM image of Ti3AlC2 showed typical bulk irregular shapes (Fig. 2b). The surface morphology was dramatically transformed after oxidation and alkalization hydrothermal treatment. Remarkably, by varying the alkaline medium (NaOH for T-NTO and KOH for T-KTO),  the products exhibited different morphologies of urchin-like nanofibers (Fig. S1a, Fig. S1b and Fig. 2d) and kelp-like nanoribbons (Fig. S1c and Fig. 2g), respectively. In addition, a high-magnification SEM image further revealed the morphology of T-NTO nanofibers and T-KTO nanoribbons (Fig. 2a and Fig. 2c). High-resolution TEM (HRTEM) images of margin zone (Fig. 2e) further manifested the lattice spacings of 0.75 nm, corresponding to the (001) planes of the NTO phase.22 Meanwhile, an interlayer spacing of 0.86 nm, corresponding to the (200) plane of KTO, was presented in Fig 3i.23 However, the sheet of intermediate zone is too thick to pierce to the attacking of the electron. The TEM image of Fig. S1d showed that the surface of TAC was very smooth. Based on the above characterization, a possible conclusion could be that NTO and KTO phases occurred on the magin of TAC after oxidation and alkalization treatment, which was attributed to the super high chemical stability of TAC.24 Moreover,  the color also changed from black to gray and light yellow, suggesting the successful transformation to T-NTO and T-

sections.heading: KTO.
sections.text:
Fig. 2 (a‐c) SEM images of T‐NTO Ti3AlC2, and T‐KTO; (d,g) TEM images of T‐ NTO and T‐KTO; (e, f) HRTEM images of T‐NTO and T‐KTO.
Furthermore, the crystal structure transformation was also examined by XRD (Fig. 3). Very sharp diffraction peaks at 9.52°, 19.2°, 33.9°, and 39.0° were assigned to the Ti3AlC2 crystal phase (PDF card 52-0875), well consistent with previous reports. 25,26 It was found that these typical peak intensities of Ti3AlC2 were significantly decreased after oxidation and alkalization treatment.  Meanwhile, new peaks at 2θ = 9.87°, 24.36°, 28.38° and 34.63° were indexed to (100), (201), (111) and (112) plane of typical primitive monoclinic Na2Ti3O7 (NTO) (PDF card 31-1329), respectively.27-29 Similarly, the appearance of peaks at 10.07°, 23.97°, 28.96° and 47.96° corresponded to (200), (110), (402), and (020) plane of monoclinic K2Ti4O9 (KTO) phase (PDF Number 32-0861).30 Despite

the formation of main peaks, it can be readily observed that some of the characteristic reflections of NTO and KTO were still missing. The missing reflections were probably due to low-concentration impurity phases and partial crystallization of titanate phase, as also found by previous results.31-32 To determine the components of TNTO and T-KTO, the obtained nanocomposites were dissolved into 20 M HNO3 solution, respectively. The molar ratio of metal elements was measured by inductively coupled plasma optic emission spectrometer (ICP-OES). Thus, Na2Ti3O7 component in T-NTO was ~ 49.2 wt%, while content of K2Ti4O9 in T-KTO was ~ 44.4 wt% based on ICP analysis (Tables S1). The valence state of as-prepared materials was further determined with the aid of XPS investigations. As shown in Fig. 4a, an apparent Na 1s signal at 1017.0 eV and K 2p signal (K 2p1/2 ∼295.1 eV, K 2p3/2 ∼292.3 eV) were emerged for TNTO and T-KTO, respectively.27 The peaks at approximately 463.8 eV and 458.0 eV corresponding to Ti 2p1/2 and Ti 2p3/2 could be ascribed to the formation of oxidized Ti(IV) (Fig. 4b).33 The Raman spectra (Fig.4c) were in accordance with those of titanate materials with preious report. The peaks located at 885 cm−1 and 923 cm−1 in T-NTO were triggered by short Ti-O stretching vibrations coordinated with Na+.34 Similarly, for the T-KTO, the peak at 903 cm−1 was the characteristic of the Ti-O stretching vibration related to K+.35 The peak at 442 cm-1 represented the Ti-O bending vibration involving six-coordinated titanium and three-coordinated oxygen atoms in the [TiO6] octahedron. FT-IR spectra were employed for the chemical constitutions on the T-NTO and T-KTO. Peaks at 900 cm-1 and 953 cm-1 for both T-NTO and T-KTO were typical the stretching vibrations of Ti-O involving non-bridging oxygen atoms.32 The bands at ~1396 cm-1 and 3410 cm-1 were characteristic of the bending vibrations of Ti-OH and stretching vibration of -OH, respectively (Fig. 4d).36
The foregoing analyses confirmed the successful fabrication of TNTO and T-KTO during the simultaneous oxidation and alkalization treatment. To explore the proposed mechanism for the titanate formation process, the XRD patterns were monitored at different reaction condition and shown in Fig. S2. As for the oxidized Ti3AlC2 without involving NaOH treatment (denoted as H2O2-TAC), an appearance of TiO2 peak was successfully recorded as comparison with the pristine Ti3AlC2. However, no significant change was observed on the alkalized Ti3AlC2 (denoted as NaOH-TAC). This phenomenon verified that the surface of TAC was partially oxidized with aid of H2O2. Herein, a reasonable mechanism was proposed for the formation process of TAC-derived NTO and KTO. As the precursor, The surface of TAC could be partially converted into titanium oxycarbides (TiO2) during the rapid oxidation treatment. And then, the sodium/potassium titanates were further formed under the alkalization process under the alkalization process of titanium oxycarbides. The transformation of chemical mechanisms might be concluded as the following equations :
Ti3AlC2 + x H2O2 = Ti3- x AlC2 + xTiO2 + x H2↑ (a) 3TiO2+2NaOH = Na2Ti3O7+H2O (b1) 4TiO2+2KOH = K2Ti4O9+H2O (b2)
Subsequently, the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were shown in the Fig. 4e and 4f, the BET specific surface areas of T-NTO and TKTO were determined to be 62.4 m2/g and 57.8 m2/g, respectively. It was worth mentioning that these values were superior to those of pristine TAC, suggestive of the successful reformation of structure
and morphology.24 As calculated by pore structure parameters, the average pore sizes were situated at diameters of 3.7 nm for T-NTO and 3.5 nm for T-KTO, indicting the existence of mesopores.37 Benefiting from the facile preparation method, abundant functional groups and increased specific surface areas, such MAX-derived titanates were highly expected to be the promising candidates for wastewater remediation.  
 
Fig 3. XRD patterns of Ti3AlC2, T‐NTO and T‐KTO. 
Effect of solid content  
It is well-known that an appropriate solid content (m/V) was a crucial factor for influencing the adsorption process.38 As graphed in Fig. 5a, the adsorption percentage of Pb(II) underwent a remarkable increase from ~ 71.8% to ~ 95.8% with T-NTO content increased from 0.05 to 0.8 g/L. The adsorption behavior of Pb(II) on T-KTO presented an analogous tendency to that of Pb(II) on T-NTO (Fig. 5b). Since the adsorption efficiency of T-NTO can reach 92.3% at 0.2 g∙L-1, which is seen as an appropriate solid content for the following batch investigations. The batch experiments of T-KTO are also carried out under this condition for the fair comparison. It was necessary to point out that the Qe values of Pb(II) on T-NTO and TKTO decreased obviously with the increase of m/V. At high m/V conditions, the available adsorption sites of adsorbents would be constrained, which might be responsible for the decreased Qe value. Another reason may be the aggregation of solid particles, further reducing the complexation action between the binding sites and Pb(II).39

Fig. 4 (a) XPS spectra of T‐NTO and T‐KTO; (b) Ti 2p of T‐NTO and T‐KTO; FT‐ IR spectra (c) Raman spectra (d) of T‐NTO and T‐KTO before and after Pb(II)  removal;  (e,  f)  N2  adsorption‐desorption  isotherms  of  T‐NTO  and  T‐KTO  (insets are the pore size distribution). 
Kinetics studies 
Fig. 5c and 5d diagrammed the plots of adsorbed Pb(II) versus the adsorption time. It was worth noting that the removal percentages of Pb(II) on T-NTO and T-KTO reached 90.0% and 68.0% within the initial 1h, then the equilibrium state being achieved slowly. The high elimination rates of Pb(II) in the initial stage were mainly associated with the abundant free available adsorption sites on the surface. As summarized in Table S2, the adsorption rate of T-NTO towards Pb(II) was superior as compared with that of T-KTO, which might be attributed to the former’s highly active sites, further boosted the adsorption energy between adsorbents and Pb(II). To get insight into the underlying adsorption behavior, the kinetic data was mimicked by two typical kinetic models, which were exhibited in SI section. The plot of t/Qt vs t (h) disclosed a perfect linear relation (correlation coefficient values R2 = 0.999), which was a typical characteristic for pseudo-second-order processes (insets of Fig. 5c and 5d), suggesting the adsorption process was substantially under a chemical reaction.

Fig. 5 (a, b) Effect of solid content on Pb(II) adsorption to T‐NTO and T‐KTO; (c,  d)  The  kinetics  studies  of  Pb(II)  adsorption  on  T‐NTO  and  T‐KTO.  All  experiments were performed at T = 298K, pH = 5.0 ± 0.1, C0(Pb(II)) = 10 mg/L,  C(NaNO3) = 0.01 M. 
Effect of pH  
Generally speaking, solution pH as an important factor affect the surface charge of adsorbents, existent forms of Pb(II) species and protonation degree of surface functional groups.40 The effect of pH towards Pb(II) on T-NTO and T-KTO was carefully investigated. As observed in Fig. 6a, the uptake percentage of T-NTO increased rapidly from ∼44% to ∼92% with increasing pH (2.5-6.5), maintained the elevated level, followed by a slight descend at pH > 9.5. Similar tendency was also observed for the T-KTO/Pb systems. The above results can be explained by the inherent properties of the adsorbents and the species distribution of Pb(II) in  aqueous solution. Obviously, the point of zero charge (pHpzc) of T-NTO and T-KTO were approximately 2.75 and 3.02, indicative of both the two products carried the highly positive surface charge under strong acidic condition (Fig. 6b). Calculated by Visual MINTEQ ver. 3.0, the relative distribution of Pb(II) species were shown in the Fig. S3. It was noteworthy that the positive charged (Pb2+) was the major existing species at pH < 6.5. Accordingly, the electrostatic repulsion together with competition with H+ were mainly responsible for the unsatisfactory removal performance at low pH. As pH increased from pHPZC to 6.5, the enlarged adsorption percentage probably arose from the effective electrostatic attraction between negative adsorbents surface and positive charged Pb(II) species (Pb2+ and Pb(OH)+).41-43 While at high pH values, several negatively charged OH- were capable of competing with negatively charged Pb(OH)3-, leading to the negative effect on ion exchange, which further impeded the elimination of Pb(II) process. 5,44

Thermodynamic study  With the aim of exploring adsorption mechanisms and evaluating adsorption performance, the adsorption thermodynamic studies were exhibited in Fig. 6c and 6d. It was quite clear that the higher temperature was beneficial to the adsorption performance of Pb(II) (328K > 313K > 298K). the Langmuir and Freundlich models were

where Ce (mg/L) is the Pb(II) concentration at equilibrium, qmax (mg/g) represents the topmost adsorption capacity on theoretical level, and qe (mg/g) represents the amount of Pb(II) adsorbed on the adsorbents. b (L/ mg) and n are considered as the constants of the Langmuir and Freundlich models, respectively. The related parameters were summarized in Table 1, all manifested a well agreement with the Langmuir model, indicating that immobilization of Pb(II) process was a monolayer coverage process.47 The topmost capacity of Pb(II) adsorption on T-NTO was calculated to be 328.9 mg g-1, which was larger than that of T-KTO (248.3 mg g-1). One possible explanation, which is proposed for the T-NTO with superior adsorption performance, was that the larger specific surface area could offer more binding locations to promote Pb(II) uptake.48 An alternative explanation was considered from the variance of radius between K+ and Na+ in the titanate surface and interlayer. It was well known that the ion-exchange is more favorable between the adsorbate and ions with smaller radius size.4,29 49 Hence, Na+ with smaller radius (0.102 nm), was more prone to complete the ion exchange with Pb(II), thereby endowing T-NTO with a higher adsorption efficiency for Pb(II) than T-KTO, which was also reported by Xu et al..50 In addition, as compared with majority of previously reported nanomaterials, the extraordinary adsorption capacity of T-NTO makes it one of the most effective Pb(II) adsorbents. 51,52
Herein, the thermodynamic parameters, i.e., ∆G0 (free energy), ∆H0 (enthalpy change) and ∆S0 (entropy change), were calculated to reveal the thermodynamic viability (see the detailed information in the SI). As summarized in Table S3, the positive ΔH0 values further proved that the elimination process of Pb(II) on T-NTO and T-KTO was an endothermic reaction. Meanwhile, it could be well accepted that the adsorption reaction was spontaneous, as a result of the positive ∆S0 and negative ΔG0 values.53 Attractively, the ∆G0 values on T-NTO were more negative than those of Pb(II) on T-KTO, reflecting that the adsorption process of Pb(II) on T-NTO was more spontaneous as comparison with T-KTO. Interaction mechanism  
To probe the adsorption mechanism specifically, FT-IR and Raman spectra were collected on T-NTO and T-KTO before and after adsorption (Fig. 4). The Raman spectra after Pb(II) adsorption (labelled as T-NTO + Pb2+ and T-KTO + Pb2+) clearly illustrated a remarkable change of molecular structure information (Fig. 4d). The peaks at 886 cm-1 and 917 cm-1 (Ti-O-Na) merged and shifted to lower intensity, providing a direct proof for the fractional replacement of Na+ by Pb(II).54,55 Similarly, the changed Ti-OK peak at 903 cm-1 for T-KTO was attributed to the short Ti-O vibrations affected by the target ions. However, there are no obvious change or shift towards the peaks of 442 cm-1 after adsorption, signifying the stability of [TiO6] octahedron in the adsorption process. Those phenomena confirmed that ion exchange between Pb(II) and the interlayered Na+ ions was the key mechanism for Pb(II) removal.56 As for the FT-IR spectra (Fig. 4c), upon adsorption of Pb (II), it was clear that the peaks of -ONa (900 cm-1) and -OK (953 cm-1) groups shifted to 907 cm-1 and 960 cm-1, due to ion exchange of Na+ /K+ in - ONa/OK with Pb (II).56 The XRD patterns after Pb(II) uptake were shown in Fig. S4, the interlayer spacing (d100 spacing) of T-NTO decreased from 0.902 nm to 0.864 nm caused by ion exchange strongly, suggesting that the replacement of Na+ in the interlayer of T-NTO resulted in the interlayer shrinking.57 Similarly, the d spacing of T-KTO decreased from 0.884 nm to 0.830 nm. To better clarify the cause of the dissimilarities of elimination capacity on T-NTO and T-KTO deeply, XPS spectra were further recorded in Fig. 7a and 7b, which were calibrated by C 1s peak at 284.6 eV (see Fig. S5). As seen from Fig. 7a, the decrement of Na 1s (from 16.53% to 10.31%) and K 2p (from 12.54% to 8.76%) peaks, together with the appearance of two peaks of Pb 4f, which further reasonably confirmed the ion-exchange mechanism, being in good agreement with Raman, FT-IR and XRD results.19 Similar behavior was also reported by Liu et al.58,59 and other references.60-63 In the highresolution of O 1s spectra (Fig.7c and 7d), the peak of 529.6 eV was corresponded to the crystal lattice [TiO6]. Additionally, the peak located at 530.1 eV was identified to Ti-OH, which can be assigned to the surface complexation site.64 After Pb(II) adsorption, the binding energy of Ti-OH (530.1 eV ) was shifted to higher binding energy for T-NTO (530.4 eV) and T-KTO (530.2 eV), respectively, which could be traceable to the donation of electrons from O 1s and the formation of Pb-O bonding. The finding herein suggested that the surface complexation site plays important role during the adsorption process of Pb(II).65 As summarized in Table 2, it was evident that the Ti 2p peaks of T-NTO and T-KTO also moved to higher binding energies, which were caused by the donation effect of the outmost O and the subsequent induce effect between Ti-OH (Fig. 7e and 7f). Notably, the Ti 2p bonding shift of T-NTO (0.4 eV) was larger than that of T-KTO (0.2 eV), which was in good agreement of O 1s, indicating a stronger interaction between T-NTO and Pb(II). In brief, T-NTO possessed higher adsorption capacity than T-KTO owing to the former’s higher affinity and stronger complexation force to bind with Pb(II). These finding was well in accordance with the thermodynamics results.

Fig. 7  (a) XPS spectra of T‐NTO and T‐KTO before and after Pb(II)  removal;  XPS spectra of Pb 4f (b), O 1s (c, d), and Ti 2p (e, f).    
The aforementioned results and analyses provided a strong proof for the elimination of Pb(II) on T-NTO and T-KTO. As a result, the ion exchange and surface complexation were the key adsorption mechanisms for capturing Pb(II). Herein, taking the T-NTO as example, the removal process of Pb(II) was expressed by the following steps. Originally, the Pb(II) ions and the negatively charged surface sites are combined through the electrostatic attraction. And then Pb(II) ions are assumed to exchange with Na+ in the layered titanate. The surface complexation between Pb(II) with the surface functional groups (Ti-OH) of layer edges occurred in the adsorption process simultaneously.
Table 2 Binding energies of elements in T‐NTO and T‐KTO before and after  Pb(II) adsorption. 
  O 1s Ti 2p
Ti-OH [TiO6] Ti 2p1/2 Ti 2p3/2
T-NTO 530.1 eV 529.6 eV 463.6 eV 457.8 eV
T-NTO-Pb(II) 530.4 eV 529.7 eV 464.0 eV 458.2 eV
T-KTO 530.1 eV 529.6 eV 463.8 eV 458.1 eV
T-KTO-Pb(II) 530.2 eV 529.6 eV 464.0eV 458.3 eV
Conclusions  To conclude, presented above was a systematic investigation on the adsorption behavior of Pb(II) onto 2D MAX@titanate nanostructures, which were synthesized by a straightforward oxidation and alkalization. Notably, the morphologies of TACderived titanate can be easily regulated by varying the type of alkali source. The urchin-like T-NTO nanofibers and kelp-like T-KTO nanosheets were successfully confirmed as effective adsorbents for targeted removal of Pb(II), with a fast removal rate and outstanding adsorption capacity. Based on the results of spectroscopic (FTIR,
Raman and XPS), the possible mechanism was well elaborated, in which the synergistic effect of surface complexation and ion exchange made tremendous contribution to the excellent adsorption performation. More importantly, benefiting from the higher specific surface area, stronger complexation capacity and smaller size of interlayer ions, the resulting T-NTO nanofibers exhibited a superior potential for Pb(II) adsorption. Therefore, the multiple advantages, including fluoride-free methodology and high adsorption capacities, made the MAX@titanate a promising candidate for environmental remediation.
